quizzes.question:
Fill in the blank to select customers who live in Hollywood, CA.
[!raw!]
SELECT * FROM customers 
WHERE state = 'CA'
{0} city = 'Hollywood'
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Logical Operators[/h1]

Logical operators can be used to combine two Boolean values and return a result of  [b]true[/b], [b]false[/b], or [b]null[/b].
The following operators can be used: [img id="2809" width="100%"]
When retrieving data using a SELECT statement, use logical operators in the WHERE clause to combine multiple conditions.

If you want to select rows that satisfy all of the given conditions, use the logical operator, [b]AND[/b].  [img id="2810" width="100%"]
To find the names of the customers between 30 to 40 years of age, set up the query as seen here:[code format="sql"]SELECT ID, FirstName, LastName, Age
FROM customers
WHERE Age >= 30 [b]AND[/b] Age <= 40;[/code]
This results in the following output: [img id="2811" width="100%"]
[note]You can combine as many conditions as needed to return the desired results.[/note]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to select customers who live either in CA or in Boston.
[!raw!]
SELECT name, state, city 
FROM customers 
{0} state = 'CA' 
{1} city = 'Boston';
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]OR[/h1]

If you want to select rows that satisfy at least one of the given conditions, you can use the logical [b]OR [/b]operator.

The following table describes how the logical [b]OR [/b]operator functions: [img id="2812" width="100%"]
For example, if you want to find the customers who live either in New York or Chicago, the query would like this: [code format="sql"]SELECT * FROM customers 
WHERE City = 'New York' [b]OR [/b]City[b] = [/b]'Chicago';[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [img id="2813" width="100%"]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to select customers whose ids are either 1 or 2, and whose city is ''Boston''.
[!raw!]
SELECT * FROM customers
WHERE (id = 1 {0} id = 2)
{1} city = 'Boston'
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Combining AND & OR[/h1]

The SQL [b]AND [/b]and [b]OR [/b]conditions may be combined to test multiple conditions in a query. 
These two operators are called [b]conjunctive operators[/b].

When combining these conditions, it is important to use [b]parentheses[/b], so that the order to evaluate each condition is known.

Consider the following table: [img id="2814" width="100%"]
The statement below selects all customers from the city "New York" [b]AND [/b]with the age equal to "30" [b]OR [/b]â€œ35":[code format="sql"]SELECT * FROM customers
WHERE City = 'New York'
[b]AND [/b](Age=30[b] OR[/b] Age=35);[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [img id="2815" width="100%"]
[note]You can nest as many conditions as you need.[/note]
